justifications: The passage begins with an introduction to the revelation and a blessing ('μακάριος ὁ ἀναγινώσκων'), which is prophetic exhortation. It includes a greeting of grace and peace ('χάρις ὑμῖν καὶ εἰρήνη') and descriptions of Jesus as 'ὁ μάρτυς ὁ πιστός, ὁ πρωτότοκος τῶν νεκρῶν καὶ ὁ ἄρχων τῶν βασιλέων τῆς γῆς,' which leans toward victory and hope. The phrase 'αὐτῷ ἡ δόξα καὶ τὸ κράτος εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων' is clear worship and praise. The statement 'Ἰδοὺ ἔρχεται μετὰ τῶν νεφελῶν, καὶ ὄψεται αὐτὸν πᾶς ὀφθαλμὸς καὶ οἵτινες αὐτὸν ἐξεκέντησαν, καὶ κόψονται ἐπʼ αὐτὸν πᾶσαι αἱ φυλαὶ τῆς γῆς' suggests both theophanic awe and judicial wrath. The 'Ἐγώ εἰμι τὸ Ἄλφα καὶ τὸ Ὦ' statement is a theophanic declaration. The initial description of the book as an 'ἀποκάλυψις' and the identification of John as a 'δούλῳ' are more neutral content.

The passage begins with an introduction to the revelation and a blessing ('μακάριος ὁ ἀναγινώσκων'), which is prophetic exhortation. It includes a greeting of grace and peace ('χάρις ὑμῖν καὶ εἰρήνη') and describes Jesus as 'ὁ μάρτυς ὁ πιστός, ὁ πρωτότοκος τῶν νεκρῶν καὶ ὁ ἄρχων τῶν βασιλέων τῆς γῆς,' which contributes to worship and praise. The phrase 'αὐτῷ ἡ δόξα καὶ τὸ κράτος εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων' is direct worship. The mention of his coming 'μετὰ τῶν νεφελῶν' and 'κόψονται ἐπʼ αὐτὸν πᾶσαι αἱ φυλαὶ τῆς γῆς' suggests judicial wrath and theophanic awe. The description of Jesus as 'ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν καὶ ὁ ἐρχόμενος, ὁ παντοκράτωρ' evokes theophanic awe. 'καὶ ἐποίησεν ἡμᾶς βασιλείαν, ἱερεῖς τῷ θεῷ καὶ πατρὶ αὐτοῦ' points to victory and consolation. The initial description of the revelation's purpose ('ἃ δεῖ γενέσθαι ἐν τάχει') and the address to the seven churches are more neutral content.

The passage begins with John identifying himself as a 'brother' and 'companion in tribulation' (Lament, Persecution & Endurance - 10.0). There is a strong emphasis on prophetic exhortation and warning, with the command to 'write what you see' and send it to the seven churches (Prophetic Exhortation & Warning - 20.0). The description of the glorified Christ, with eyes like fire and a sword coming from his mouth, evokes Theophanic Awe & Terror (25.0). The declaration 'I am the first and the last' and 'I have the keys of death and Hades' suggests Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope (10.0). The mention of 'tribulation' and the 'word of God' suggests Lament, Persecution & Endurance (10.0). The description of Christ's power and authority hints at Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action (5.0). The mention of the 'mystery of the seven stars' and the 'seven lampstands' falls under Other/Neutral Content (20.0), as it is primarily descriptive and sets the stage for further revelation. The phrase 'glory and honor' is implied in the description of Christ, suggesting Worship & Praise (5.0). The 'sword' from his mouth and the stars in his hand suggest Cosmic Warfare & Deception (5.0).

The passage begins with John identifying himself as a 'brother' and 'partner in tribulation' (Lament, Persecution & Endurance - 10.0). He is on Patmos 'because of the word of God and the testimony of Jesus' (Other/Neutral Content - 20.0). He receives a command to 'write what you see' and send it to the seven churches (Prophetic Exhortation & Warning - 20.0). The description of the glorified Christ is filled with imagery evoking awe and terror: 'eyes like a flame of fire,' 'voice like the sound of many waters,' 'a sharp two-edged sword coming from his mouth,' 'face shining like the sun' (Theophanic Awe & Terror - 25.0). Christ identifies himself as 'the first and the last' and 'the living one' who 'holds the keys of Death and Hades' (Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope - 10.0). The mention of 'tribulation' and Christ's power over death allude to the cosmic conflict (Cosmic Warfare & Deception - 5.0). The command to write and send to the churches is a prophetic exhortation (Prophetic Exhortation & Warning - 20.0). The description of Christ's glory hints at his worthiness of worship (Worship & Praise - 5.0). The sword from his mouth suggests judgment (Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action - 5.0).

This passage consists of letters to seven churches. 'Worship & Praise' is present but minimal (3.0%) as the focus is not direct worship but rather Christ's assessment of their actions. 'Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action' is significant (18.0%) due to threats of judgment against those who are unfaithful (e.g., 'κινήσω τὴν λυχνίαν σου', 'βάλλω αὐτὴν εἰς κλίνην', 'ἀποκτενῶ ἐν θανάτῳ', 'μέλλω σε ἐμέσαι'). 'Lament, Persecution & Endurance' (8.0%) is evident in the descriptions of suffering and trials faced by some churches ('Οἶδά σου τὴν θλῖψιν καὶ τὴν πτωχείαν', 'ἕξετε θλῖψιν'). 'Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope' (15.0%) appears in promises to the overcomers (νικῶντι), such as eating from the tree of life ('δώσω αὐτῷ φαγεῖν ἐκ τοῦ ξύλου τῆς ζωῆς'), receiving a crown of life ('δώσω σοι τὸν στέφανον τῆς ζωῆς'), and becoming a pillar in God's temple ('ποιήσω αὐτὸν στῦλον ἐν τῷ ναῷ τοῦ θεοῦ μου'). 'Cosmic Warfare & Deception' (12.0%) is present in references to Satan's throne ('ὅπου ὁ θρόνος τοῦ Σατανᾶ'), the synagogue of Satan ('συναγωγῆς τοῦ Σατανᾶ'), and Jezebel's deception ('πλανᾷ τοὺς ἐμοὺς δούλους'). 'Prophetic Exhortation & Warning' (30.0%) is dominant, with repeated calls to repent ('μετανόησον'), warnings against false teachings ('ἔχω κατὰ σοῦ ὅτι ἀφεῖς τὴν γυναῖκα Ἰεζάβελ'), and commands to listen ('ὁ ἔχων οὖς ἀκουσάτω'). 'Theophanic Awe & Terror' (4.0%) is suggested by descriptions of Christ's appearance ('ὁ ἔχων τοὺς ὀφθαλμοὺς αὐτοῦ ὡς φλόγα πυρός'), but it is not a primary focus. 'Other/Neutral Content' (10.0%) includes introductory phrases and descriptive elements that do not strongly align with the other categories.

The passage describes John's vision of an open door in heaven and a voice like a trumpet commanding him to 'Come up here' (Ἀνάβα ὧδε). The presence of a throne (θρόνος) and someone seated upon it (καθήμενος) evokes theophanic awe. The command to 'Come up here' is a prophetic exhortation. The description of the throne in heaven suggests a setting for worship, though it is not explicitly stated. The majority of the text is descriptive, setting the scene for future revelations, thus falling under 'Other/Neutral Content'.

The passage is dominated by scenes of heavenly worship and the awe-inspiring presence of God on his throne. "Ἅγιος ἅγιος ἅγιος κύριος, ὁ θεός, ὁ παντοκράτωρ" and "Ἄξιος εἶ, ὁ κύριος καὶ ὁ θεὸς ἡμῶν, λαβεῖν τὴν δόξαν καὶ τὴν τιμὴν καὶ τὴν δύναμιν" exemplify the worship and praise (40%). The description of the throne room, the lightning, voices, thunder, and the sea of glass contribute to the theophanic awe and terror (25%). The initial lament of John "ἔκλαιον πολὺ" and the subsequent consolation "Μὴ κλαῖε" represent lament and hope (5%). The worthiness of the Lamb to open the scroll and the resulting kingdom of priests contribute to the victory and new creation hope (15%). The descriptions of the throne, the creatures, and the elders provide neutral content (15%). There is no judicial wrath or cosmic warfare present in this section.

"ἅγιος ἅγιος ἅγιος κύριος, ὁ θεός, ὁ παντοκράτωρ" and "Ἄξιος εἶ, ὁ κύριος καὶ ὁ θεὸς ἡμῶν, λαβεῖν τὴν δόξαν καὶ τὴν τιμὴν καὶ τὴν δύναμιν" exemplify the worship and praise (40%). The description of the throne room, lightning, voices, thunder, and the sea of glass contribute to the theophanic awe and terror (25%). The initial weeping of John and the elder's consolation contribute to lament and hope (5% and 15% respectively). The descriptions of the creatures and elders, along with narrative transitions, are categorized as other/neutral content (15%).

"Ἅγιος ἅγιος ἅγιος κύριος, ὁ θεός, ὁ παντοκράτωρ" and "Ἄξιος εἶ, ὁ κύριος καὶ ὁ θεὸς ἡμῶν, λαβεῖν τὴν δόξαν καὶ τὴν τιμὴν καὶ τὴν δύναμιν" exemplify the worship and praise (40%). The description of the throne room, the lightning, voices, thunder, and the sea of glass contribute to the theophanic awe and terror (25%). The initial lament of John "ἔκλαιον πολὺ" and the subsequent consolation "Μὴ κλαῖε" represent lament and hope (5%). The worthiness of the Lamb to open the scroll and the resulting kingdom of priests contribute to the victory and new creation hope (15%). The descriptions of the throne, the creatures, and the elders provide neutral content (15%). There is no judicial wrath or cosmic warfare present in this section.

The passage details the opening of the seals, unleashing judgments: war ("ἵππος πυρρός... μάχαιρα μεγάλη"), famine ("ἵππος μέλας... ζυγὸν"), death ("ἵππος χλωρός... Θάνατος"), and cosmic disturbances ("σεισμὸς μέγας... ὁ ἥλιος ἐγένετο μέλας"). This constitutes Judicial Wrath (40%). The souls under the altar crying out "Ἕως πότε, ὁ δεσπότης" represents Lament (15%). The promise of white robes and rest suggests Victory/Consolation (5%). The horses and their riders, along with the mention of beasts, indicate Cosmic Warfare (10%). The earthquake and falling stars evoke Theophanic Awe (20%). The opening of the seals and the initial descriptions of the riders are categorized as Other/Neutral (10%).

The passage details the opening of the seals, unleashing judgments upon the earth. The four horsemen bring war, famine, and death (Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action - 40.0). The souls under the altar cry out for justice ('Ἕως πότε, ὁ δεσπότης ὁ ἅγιος καὶ ἀληθινός, οὐ κρίνεις καὶ ἐκδικεῖς τὸ αἷμα ἡμῶν') expressing lament and persecution (Lament, Persecution & Endurance - 15.0). They are given white robes and told to rest, hinting at future vindication (Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope - 5.0). The horsemen themselves represent cosmic forces (Cosmic Warfare & Deception - 10.0). The earthquake, darkening of the sun and moon, falling stars, and the terror of the people hiding in caves ('σεισμὸς μέγας ἐγένετο,' 'ὁ ἥλιος ἐγένετο μέλας,' 'οἱ ἀστέρες τοῦ οὐρανοῦ ἔπεσαν,' 'Πέσετε ἐφʼ ἡμᾶς καὶ κρύψατε ἡμᾶς ἀπὸ προσώπου τοῦ καθημένου ἐπὶ τοῦ θρόνου καὶ ἀπὸ τῆς ὀργῆς τοῦ ἀρνίου') evoke theophanic awe and terror (Theophanic Awe & Terror - 25.0). The opening descriptions of the seals and the creatures saying 'Ἔρχου' are considered neutral narrative elements (Other/Neutral Content - 5.0).

The passage begins with angels holding back the winds, preventing destruction ('ἵνα μὴ πνέῃ ἄνεμος ἐπὶ τῆς γῆς'), which suggests potential 'Judicial Wrath' (5%). The sealing of the 144,000 is a protective act, but also a preparatory one (Other/Neutral Content 30%). The multitude before the throne praising God and the Lamb ('Ἡ σωτηρία τῷ θεῷ ἡμῶν') is a clear expression of 'Worship & Praise' (25%). The description of those coming out of great tribulation ('ἐκ τῆς θλίψεως τῆς μεγάλης') and having their robes washed white points to 'Lament, Persecution & Endurance' (10%). The promise that they will no longer hunger or thirst, and that God will wipe away every tear ('καὶ ἐξαλείψει ὁ θεὸς πᾶν δάκρυον ἐκ τῶν ὀφθαλμῶν αὐτῶν') signifies 'Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope' (20%). The command not to harm the earth ('Μὴ ἀδικήσητε τὴν γῆν') is a 'Prophetic Exhortation & Warning' (5%). The vision of the throne and the Lamb evokes 'Theophanic Awe & Terror' (5%).

The passage begins with angels holding back the winds, preventing destruction ('ἵνα μὴ πνέῃ ἄνεμος ἐπὶ τῆς γῆς'), which suggests potential 'Judicial Wrath' (5%). The sealing of the 144,000 is a protective act, a 'Prophetic Exhortation' to wait (5%). The multitude before the throne, clothed in white robes and holding palms, signifies 'Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope' (25%), especially with the declaration 'Ἡ σωτηρία τῷ θεῷ ἡμῶν' ('Salvation belongs to our God'). The angels' prostration and worship, saying 'ἡ εὐλογία καὶ ἡ δόξα καὶ ἡ σοφία' ('blessing and glory and wisdom'), clearly indicates 'Worship & Praise' (25%). The description of those coming out of 'τῆς θλίψεως τῆς μεγάλης' ('the great tribulation') and having their robes washed in the Lamb's blood points to 'Lament, Persecution & Endurance' (10%). The Lamb shepherding them to springs of water and God wiping away tears also contributes to 'Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope'. The initial vision of the angels and the throne room evokes 'Theophanic Awe & Terror' (5%). The lists of tribes and the elder's questions and answers are categorized as 'Other/Neutral Content' (25%) as they provide narrative context and transition.

The opening of the seventh seal ('ἤνοιξεν τὴν σφραγῖδα τὴν ἑβδόμην') and the resulting silence in heaven ('ἐγένετο σιγὴ ἐν τῷ οὐρανῷ') evokes a sense of theophanic awe and anticipation of something momentous. The silence itself, described as 'ὡς ἡμιώριον' (about half an hour), heightens the tension and suggests a pregnant pause before a significant event. The opening of the seal is a narrative transition, but the silence is more than just neutral content; it creates a sense of expectation and dread. Therefore, 'Theophanic Awe & Terror' is assigned 40%, and 'Other/Neutral Content' is assigned 60% to account for the narrative transition and the description of the silence.

Therefore, 'Theophanic Awe & Terror' is assigned 40%, and 'Other/Neutral Content' is assigned 60% to account for the narrative transition and the description of the silence.

The opening of the seventh seal is a significant event, marked by silence in heaven for about half an hour (σιγὴ ἐν τῷ οὐρανῷ ὡς ἡμιώριον). This silence, following the dramatic events of the previous seals, evokes a sense of anticipation and awe, suggesting a moment of profound importance and potential theophanic terror. The silence itself is the primary element contributing to the 'Theophanic Awe & Terror' category. The rest of the verse is descriptive, setting the stage for what follows, and thus falls under 'Other/Neutral Content'.

The passage heavily emphasizes 'Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action' through the trumpet judgments: hail and fire mixed with blood (8:7), a burning mountain thrown into the sea (8:8), a star falling and poisoning the waters (8:10-11), and darkness (8:12). 'Cosmic Warfare & Deception' is evident in the locusts from the abyss (9:3-11) and the army from the Euphrates (9:13-19). 'Theophanic Awe & Terror' is present in the initial description of the angel at the altar with incense and the subsequent thunder, voices, lightning, and earthquake (8:3-5), as well as the smoke from the abyss (9:2). 'Prophetic Exhortation & Warning' is seen in the eagle's cry of 'Woe, woe, woe' (8:13) and the description of the consequences of not repenting (9:20-21). 'Worship & Praise' is subtly present in the incense offered with the prayers of the saints (8:3-4). 'Lament, Persecution & Endurance' is reflected in the suffering of those tormented by the locusts (9:5-6). 'Other/Neutral Content' accounts for descriptive passages and narrative transitions. There is no explicit 'Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope' in this section.

The passage begins with a theophanic vision of a mighty angel descending from heaven, described with awe-inspiring imagery: "περιβεβλημένον νεφέλην, καὶ ἡ ἶρις ἐπὶ τὴν κεφαλὴν αὐτοῦ, καὶ τὸ πρόσωπον αὐτοῦ ὡς ὁ ἥλιος, καὶ οἱ πόδες αὐτοῦ ὡς στῦλοι πυρός" (clothed with a cloud, a rainbow on his head, his face like the sun, and his feet like pillars of fire). This contributes significantly to 'Theophanic Awe & Terror'. The angel's oath "τῷ ζῶντι εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων" (to the one who lives forever and ever) and the statement that "ἐτελέσθη τὸ μυστήριον τοῦ θεοῦ" (the mystery of God would be fulfilled) contribute to 'Worship & Praise' and 'Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope'. The command to John to take and eat the scroll, and then prophesy again, represents 'Prophetic Exhortation & Warning'. The majority of the passage consists of narrative description and dialogue, which falls under 'Other/Neutral Content'. The angel's description and the thunder contribute to the 'Theophanic Awe & Terror' category. The statement about the mystery of God being fulfilled contributes to 'Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope'.

The passage begins with a theophanic vision of a mighty angel descending from heaven, described with awe-inspiring imagery: "περιβεβλημένον νεφέλην, καὶ ἡ ἶρις ἐπὶ τὴν κεφαλὴν αὐτοῦ, καὶ τὸ πρόσωπον αὐτοῦ ὡς ὁ ἥλιος, καὶ οἱ πόδες αὐτοῦ ὡς στῦλοι πυρός" (Theophanic Awe & Terror). The angel's oath by the one who lives forever and created all things suggests worship and praise, and the declaration that "χρόνος οὐκέτι ἔσται" hints at eschatological hope (Worship & Praise, Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope). The command to seal up what the seven thunders spoke and the instruction to John to eat the scroll are prophetic exhortations (Prophetic Exhortation & Warning). The narrative elements, such as the angel's actions and John's eating of the scroll, along with the explanation of its sweet and bitter taste, are categorized as Other/Neutral Content because they primarily serve to advance the narrative and don't strongly emphasize any of the other categories. The final command to prophesy again is a clear prophetic exhortation (Prophetic Exhortation & Warning).

The passage contains elements of measuring the temple (Other/Neutral), prophecy of the two witnesses (Prophetic Exhortation), their persecution and death (Lament, Persecution & Endurance), their power to inflict plagues (Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action), the beast making war (Cosmic Warfare & Deception), their resurrection and ascension (Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope), an earthquake and the giving of glory to God (Theophanic Awe & Terror, Worship & Praise), and the announcement of woes (Prophetic Exhortation & Warning). Specific phrases include: 'μέτρησον τὸν ναὸν τοῦ θεοῦ,' 'προφητεύσουσιν,' 'τὸ θηρίον ποιήσει μετʼ αὐτῶν πόλεμον καὶ νικήσει αὐτούς καὶ ἀποκτενεῖ αὐτούς,' 'πνεῦμα ζωῆς ἐκ τοῦ θεοῦ εἰσῆλθεν ἐν αὐτοῖς,' 'σεισμὸς μέγας,' and 'ἔδωκαν δόξαν τῷ θεῷ τοῦ οὐρανοῦ,' 'οὐαὶ ἡ δευτέρα ἀπῆλθεν.'

The passage begins with the seventh angel sounding his trumpet, followed by loud voices proclaiming, "Ἐγένετο ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ κόσμου τοῦ κυρίου ἡμῶν καὶ τοῦ χριστοῦ αὐτοῦ, καὶ βασιλεύσει εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων" (Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope). The twenty-four elders then fall on their faces and worship God, saying, "Εὐχαριστοῦμέν σοι, κύριε, ὁ θεός, ὁ παντοκράτωρ" (Worship & Praise). The phrase "καὶ τὰ ἔθνη ὠργίσθησαν, καὶ ἦλθεν ἡ ὀργή σου" indicates Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action. The phrase "καὶ ὁ καιρὸς τῶν νεκρῶν κριθῆναι καὶ δοῦναι τὸν μισθὸν τοῖς δούλοις σου τοῖς προφήταις καὶ τοῖς ἁγίοις καὶ τοῖς φοβουμένοις τὸ ὄνομά σου" also points to Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action and Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope. The phrase "καὶ διαφθεῖραι τοὺς διαφθείροντας τὴν γῆν" is a statement of divine judgment (Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action). The initial trumpet blast and the voices from heaven contribute to Theophanic Awe & Terror. The narrative introduction and transitions are categorized as Other/Neutral Content.

The passage begins with the opening of the temple and cosmic phenomena ('ἀστραπαὶ καὶ φωναὶ καὶ βρονταὶ καὶ σεισμὸς καὶ χάλαζα μεγάλη'), indicating Theophanic Awe & Terror. The appearance of the woman and the dragon signifies Cosmic Warfare & Deception ('δράκων μέγας πυρρός'). The birth of the son and his being 'caught up to God' suggests Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope. The war in heaven ('ἐγένετο πόλεμος ἐν τῷ οὐρανῷ') further emphasizes Cosmic Warfare. The voice declaring salvation and the casting down of the accuser points to both Victory and Judicial Wrath. The 'woe to the earth' is Prophetic Exhortation & Warning. The woman's flight and persecution represent Lament, Persecution & Endurance. The initial description of the opened temple and the ark, along with narrative transitions, are categorized as Other/Neutral Content. The declaration of salvation and kingdom is Worship & Praise.

The passage begins with the opening of the temple and cosmic phenomena ('ἀστραπαὶ καὶ φωναὶ καὶ βρονταὶ καὶ σεισμὸς καὶ χάλαζα μεγάλη'), indicating Theophanic Awe & Terror. The majority of the text describes the cosmic battle between the dragon and the woman, and Michael and his angels ('δράκων μέγας πυρρός,' 'ἐγένετο πόλεμος ἐν τῷ οὐρανῷ'), heavily emphasizing Cosmic Warfare & Deception. The pronouncement of salvation and the kingdom of God ('Ἄρτι ἐγένετο ἡ σωτηρία καὶ ἡ δύναμις καὶ ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ ἡμῶν') points to Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope. The dragon's wrath and pursuit of the woman ('ὠργίσθη ὁ δράκων ἐπὶ τῇ γυναικί') suggest Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action. The statement 'οὐαὶ τὴν γῆν καὶ τὴν θάλασσαν' is a Prophetic Exhortation & Warning. The saints overcoming the dragon 'καὶ αὐτοὶ ἐνίκησαν αὐτὸν διὰ τὸ αἷμα τοῦ ἀρνίου' suggests Worship & Praise and Lament, Persecution & Endurance. The description of the woman's flight and sustenance in the wilderness, and the earth helping her, falls under Other/Neutral Content.

The appearance of the woman and the dragon signifies Cosmic Warfare & Deception ('δράκων μέγας πυρρός'). The voice declaring salvation and the casting down of the accuser points to both Victory and Judicial Wrath. The 'woe to the earth' is Prophetic Exhortation & Warning. The woman's flight and persecution represent Lament, Persecution & Endurance. The initial description of the opened temple and the ark, along with narrative transitions, are categorized as Other/Neutral Content. The declaration of salvation and kingdom is Worship & Praise.

The passage begins with a vision of the Lamb and the 144,000 on Mount Zion, singing a new song before the throne (Worship & Praise). Angelic pronouncements of judgment and warnings against worshipping the beast dominate the middle section (Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action, Prophetic Exhortation & Warning). The mention of the saints' endurance ('Ὧδε ἡ ὑπομονὴ τῶν ἁγίων ἐστίν') accounts for the 'Lament, Persecution & Endurance' score. The beatitude for those who die in the Lord and the description of the redeemed being 'ἄμωμοί εἰσιν' contribute to 'Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope'. The description of Babylon's fall and the beast's mark allude to 'Cosmic Warfare & Deception'. The harvest and vintage imagery, especially the winepress of God's wrath, contribute to 'Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action'. The vision of the Son of Man on a cloud and the angels with sickles evoke 'Theophanic Awe & Terror'. Narrative elements and transitions are accounted for in 'Other/Neutral Content'.

The passage begins with a vision of angels with plagues, signaling God's wrath ('ὁ θυμὸς τοῦ θεοῦ'). The victors over the beast sing praises ('ᾄδουσιν τὴν ᾠδὴν Μωϋσέως') acknowledging God's greatness and righteousness ('Μεγάλα καὶ θαυμαστὰ τὰ ἔργα σου'). The pouring out of the bowls brings plagues and destruction ('ἐξέχεεν τὴν φιάλην αὐτοῦ εἰς τὴν γῆν'), demonstrating judicial wrath. The angel's declaration of God's justice ('Δίκαιος εἶ, ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν, ὁ ὅσιος, ὅτι ταῦτα ἔκρινας') and the altar's affirmation ('Ναί, κύριε, ὁ θεός, ὁ παντοκράτωρ, ἀληθιναὶ καὶ δίκαιαι αἱ κρίσεις σου') reinforce this. The Euphrates drying up and the gathering at Armageddon ('Ἁρμαγεδών') suggest cosmic warfare. The warning 'Ἰδοὺ ἔρχομαι ὡς κλέπτης' is prophetic exhortation. The temple filling with smoke and the inability to enter ('ἐγεμίσθη ὁ ναὸς καπνοῦ ἐκ τῆς δόξης τοῦ θεοῦ') evoke theophanic awe. The description of the plagues and the actions of the angels are categorized as 'Other/Neutral Content' as they primarily serve as narrative progression and descriptive elements, though they contribute to the overall theme of divine judgment.

The passage begins with a vision of angels with plagues, signaling God's wrath (Judicial Wrath). The victors over the beast sing praises to God and the Lamb (Worship & Praise). The temple opens, and bowls of wrath are poured out (Judicial Wrath). Plagues are described in detail (Judicial Wrath). An angel and the altar declare God's judgments are just (Worship & Praise, Judicial Wrath). The dragon, beast, and false prophet gather armies (Cosmic Warfare & Deception). A warning to be watchful is given (Prophetic Exhortation & Warning). The seventh bowl results in cosmic upheaval and destruction (Theophanic Awe & Terror, Judicial Wrath). The phrase 'Idoù ἔρχομαι ὡς κλέπτης' is a prophetic warning. The description of the plagues and the Euphrates drying up are more neutral narrative elements, as is the initial vision of the angels. The mention of the 'νικῶντας' contributes to the 'Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope' category.

The Euphrates drying up and the gathering at Armageddon ('Ἁρμαγεδών') suggest cosmic warfare. The warning 'Ἰδοὺ ἔρχομαι ὡς κλέπτης' is prophetic exhortation. The temple filling with smoke and the inability to enter ('ἐγεμίσθη ὁ ναὸς καπνοῦ ἐκ τῆς δόξης τοῦ θεοῦ') evoke theophanic awe. The description of the plagues and the actions of the angels are categorized as 'Other/Neutral Content' as they primarily serve as narrative progression and descriptive elements, though they contribute to the overall theme of divine judgment.

The passage begins with a vision of angels with plagues, signaling God's wrath (Judicial Wrath). The victors over the beast sing praises to God and the Lamb (Worship & Praise). The temple opens, and bowls of wrath are poured out (Judicial Wrath). Plagues are described in detail (Judicial Wrath). An angel and the altar declare God's judgments are just (Worship & Praise, Judicial Wrath). The dragon, beast, and false prophet gather armies (Cosmic Warfare & Deception). A warning to be watchful is given (Prophetic Exhortation & Warning). The seventh bowl results in cosmic upheaval and destruction (Theophanic Awe & Terror, Judicial Wrath). The phrase 'Idoù ἔρχομαι ὡς κλέπτης' is a prophetic warning. The description of the plagues and the Euphrates drying up are more neutral narrative elements, as is the initial vision of the angels. The mention of the 'νικῶντας' contributes to the 'Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope' category.

The passage introduces the judgment of the 'great prostitute' (τὸ κρίμα τῆς πόρνης τῆς μεγάλης), indicating Judicial Wrath (30%). The description of the prostitute and her influence on the kings of the earth and inhabitants of the earth through her 'sexual immorality' (ἐπόρνευσαν, ἐμεθύσθησαν...ἐκ τοῦ οἴνου τῆς πορνείας αὐτῆς) suggests Cosmic Warfare & Deception (25%). The angel's invitation 'Come, I will show you' (Δεῦρο, δείξω σοι) implies a Prophetic Exhortation (15%). The remaining content is narrative and descriptive, falling under Other/Neutral Content (30%).

The passage heavily features imagery of cosmic warfare and deception, particularly through the description of the woman and the beast ('θηρίον κόκκινον', 'ὀνόματα βλασφημίας', 'Βαβυλὼν ἡ μεγάλη, ἡ μήτηρ τῶν πορνῶν'). Judicial wrath is evident in the pronouncements of destruction against the harlot ('ἠρημωμένην ποιήσουσιν αὐτὴν καὶ γυμνήν, καὶ τὰς σάρκας αὐτῆς φάγονται, καὶ αὐτὴν κατακαύσουσιν ἐν πυρί'). Victory is seen in the statement that the Lamb will conquer ('τὸ ἀρνίον νικήσει αὐτούς'). Prophetic exhortation is present in the angel's explanation ('ἐγὼ ἐρῶ σοι τὸ μυστήριον'). Lament is suggested by the woman being drunk on the blood of the saints ('μεθύουσαν ἐκ τοῦ αἵματος τῶν ἁγίων'). Theophanic awe is present in John's initial reaction ('ἐθαύμασα ἰδὼν αὐτὴν θαῦμα μέγα'). Worship is implied by the Lamb being 'κύριος κυρίων ἐστὶν καὶ βασιλεὺς βασιλέων'. The remaining content is descriptive and explanatory, falling under 'Other/Neutral Content'.

Theophanic awe is present in John's initial reaction ('ἐθαύμασα ἰδὼν αὐτὴν θαῦμα μέγα'). Worship is implied by the Lamb being 'κύριος κυρίων ἐστὶν καὶ βασιλεὺς βασιλέων'. The remaining content is descriptive and explanatory, falling under 'Other/Neutral Content'.

The passage heavily features Cosmic Warfare & Deception (30%) through the description of the woman on the beast, Babylon, and their deceptive power ('γέμοντα ὀνόματα βλασφημίας', 'Βαβυλὼν ἡ μεγάλη, ἡ μήτηρ τῶν πορνῶν'). The passage contains elements of multiple categories. 'Μακάριοι οἱ εἰς τὸ δεῖπνον τοῦ γάμου τοῦ ἀρνίου κεκλημένοι' (Blessed are those who are invited to the marriage supper of the Lamb) points to 'Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope' (20%). The phrase 'τῷ θεῷ προσκύνησον' (worship God) directly indicates 'Worship & Praise' (25%). The command 'Γράψον' (Write) and the prohibition 'Ὅρα μή' (See that you do not) are instances of 'Prophetic Exhortation & Warning' (30%). The narrator falling before the feet of the angel and the angel's correction evoke 'Theophanic Awe & Terror' (10%). The statement 'Οὗτοι οἱ λόγοι ἀληθινοὶ τοῦ θεοῦ εἰσιν' (These words are true words of God) and the angel's self-identification as a fellow servant fall under 'Other/Neutral Content' (15%).

The angel's rebuke 'Ὅρα μή' (See that you do not do that!) and the command 'τῷ θεῷ προσκύνησον' (Worship God!) indicate 'Worship & Praise' (25%) and 'Theophanic Awe & Terror' (10%) due to the narrator's initial impulse to worship the angel. The statement 'σύνδουλός σού εἰμι' (I am a fellow servant with you) and 'ἡ γὰρ μαρτυρία Ἰησοῦ ἐστιν τὸ πνεῦμα τῆς προφητείας' (for the testimony of Jesus is the spirit of prophecy) are considered 'Other/Neutral Content' (15%) as they provide context and explanation without strongly fitting into the other categories.

The passage depicts Christ on a white horse ('ἵππος λευκός') and the armies of heaven, suggesting victory and theophanic awe. The description of Christ judging and waging war ('ἐν δικαιοσύνῃ κρίνει καὶ πολεμεῖ') and the winepress of God's wrath ('πατεῖ τὴν ληνὸν τοῦ οἴνου τοῦ θυμοῦ τῆς ὀργῆς τοῦ θεοῦ τοῦ παντοκράτορος') highlight judicial wrath. The call to the birds to feast on the flesh of kings and soldiers ('ἵνα φάγητε σάρκας βασιλέων') is a prophetic warning and a gruesome depiction of divine judgment. The gathering of the beast and kings for war ('τὸ θηρίον καὶ τοὺς βασιλεῖς τῆς γῆς καὶ τὰ στρατεύματα αὐτῶν συνηγμένα ποιῆσαι τὸν πόλεμον') and the capture and punishment of the beast and false prophet ('ἐπιάσθη τὸ θηρίον') represent cosmic warfare and punitive action. The names of Christ ('πιστὸς καλούμενος καὶ ἀληθινός', 'Βασιλεὺς βασιλέων καὶ κύριος κυρίων') suggest worship and praise. The initial description of heaven opening and the rider's appearance evokes theophanic awe. The 'Other/Neutral Content' accounts for narrative elements and descriptive details that don't fit neatly into the other categories.

The passage opens with a theophanic vision of heaven opening and a rider on a white horse ('καὶ εἶδον τὸν οὐρανὸν ἠνεῳγμένον, καὶ ἰδοὺ ἵππος λευκός'), inspiring awe and terror. The rider is described as 'πιστὸς καλούμενος καὶ ἀληθινός' and 'ὁ Λόγος τοῦ Θεοῦ', suggesting worship and praise. Judicial wrath is evident in the description of the rider judging and waging war ('ἐν δικαιοσύνῃ κρίνει καὶ πολεμεῖ') and treading 'τὴν ληνὸν τοῦ οἴνου τοῦ θυμοῦ τῆς ὀργῆς τοῦ θεοῦ τοῦ παντοκράτορος'. Victory and hope are present in the image of the heavenly armies following him ('τὰ στρατεύματα τὰ ἐν τῷ οὐρανῷ ἠκολούθει αὐτῷ'). Cosmic warfare is depicted in the gathering of the beast and the kings of the earth to make war ('εἶδον τὸ θηρίον καὶ τοὺς βασιλεῖς τῆς γῆς καὶ τὰ στρατεύματα αὐτῶν συνηγμένα ποιῆσαι τὸν πόλεμον'). Prophetic exhortation is seen in the angel's call to the birds to feast on the flesh of the slain ('Δεῦτε συνάχθητε εἰς τὸ δεῖπνον τὸ μέγα τοῦ θεοῦ, ἵνα φάγητε σάρκας βασιλέων'). The defeat of the beast and false prophet and their being cast into the lake of fire ('ζῶντες ἐβλήθησαν οἱ δύο εἰς τὴν λίμνην τοῦ πυρὸς') further emphasizes judicial wrath. 'Other/Neutral Content' accounts for descriptive elements and narrative transitions.

The passage describes the binding of Satan (Cosmic Warfare & Deception - 30%), his imprisonment in the abyss, and the sealing of it. It also depicts the reign of the resurrected martyrs with Christ for a thousand years (Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope - 15%) and the final defeat of Gog and Magog with fire from heaven (Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action - 20%). The blessedness of those participating in the first resurrection is mentioned (Prophetic Exhortation & Warning - 5%), along with their role as priests (Worship & Praise - 3%). The description of fire consuming the enemies and the lake of fire evokes Theophanic Awe & Terror (7%). The souls of the beheaded martyrs and their refusal to worship the beast suggests Lament, Persecution & Endurance (5%). Narrative elements and transitions are categorized as Other/Neutral Content (15%).

It also depicts the reign of the resurrected martyrs with Christ for a thousand years (Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope - 15%) and the final defeat of Gog and Magog with fire from heaven (Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action - 20%). The blessedness of those participating in the first resurrection is mentioned (Prophetic Exhortation & Warning - 5%), along with their role as priests (Worship & Praise - 3%). The description of fire consuming the enemies and the lake of fire evokes Theophanic Awe & Terror (7%). The souls of the beheaded martyrs and their refusal to worship the beast suggests Lament, Persecution & Endurance (5%). Narrative elements and transitions are categorized as Other/Neutral Content (15%).

The passage describes a great white throne and judgment ('θρόνον μέγαν λευκὸν καὶ τὸν καθήμενον ἐπʼ αὐτοῦ,' 'ἐκρίθησαν οἱ νεκροὶ'). The casting of death and Hades into the lake of fire ('καὶ ὁ θάνατος καὶ ὁ ᾅδης ἐβλήθησαν εἰς τὴν λίμνην τοῦ πυρός') and the fate of those not found in the book of life ('καὶ εἴ τις οὐχ εὑρέθη ἐν τῇ βίβλῳ τῆς ζωῆς γεγραμμένος, ἐβλήθη εἰς τὴν λίμνην τοῦ πυρός') clearly indicate Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action (40%). The mention of the 'book of life' ('βιβλίον τῆς ζωῆς') hints at Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope (10%). The description of the throne and the fleeing of earth and heaven evokes Theophanic Awe & Terror (25%). The rest of the passage contains narrative elements and descriptions of the judgment process, which are categorized as Other/Neutral Content (25%).

The passage describes a great white throne and judgment ('θρόνον μέγαν λευκὸν καὶ τὸν καθήμενον ἐπʼ αὐτοῦ'), inspiring awe and terror. The judgment of the dead based on their deeds ('ἐκρίθησαν οἱ νεκροὶ ἐκ τῶν γεγραμμένων ἐν τοῖς βιβλίοις κατὰ τὰ ἔργα αὐτῶν') and the casting of death and Hades into the lake of fire ('καὶ ὁ θάνατος καὶ ὁ ᾅδης ἐβλήθησαν εἰς τὴν λίμνην τοῦ πυρός') represent judicial wrath. The opening of the book of life ('ἄλλο βιβλίον ἠνοίχθη, ὅ ἐστιν τῆς ζωῆς') and the implication of salvation for those whose names are written there suggest victory and hope. The description of the throne and the fleeing of earth and heaven ('ἔφυγεν ἡ γῆ καὶ ὁ οὐρανός') contributes to the theophanic awe. The rest is narrative description.

The passage begins with the vision of a 'new heaven and a new earth' and the 'holy city, new Jerusalem' descending from God (Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope). God dwelling with humanity and wiping away tears, with no more death, mourning, or pain, strongly emphasizes this theme. The declaration 'I am making everything new' (καινα ποιῶ παντα) reinforces this. The statement 'These words are trustworthy and true' (πιστοὶ καὶ ἀληθινοί εἰσιν) is a Prophetic Exhortation. The description of the fate of the 'cowardly, unbelieving, vile, murderers, sexually immoral, those who practice magic arts, idolaters and all liars' being cast into the lake of fire (Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action) is a clear warning. The 'Alpha and Omega' declaration evokes Theophanic Awe. The promise of water from the spring of life to the thirsty and inheritance to the one who overcomes (ὁ νικῶν κληρονομήσει ταῦτα) falls under Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope and Prophetic Exhortation. The initial description of the new heaven and earth and the city's descent, along with the command to 'Write!' and the statement 'It is done' (Γέγοναν), are categorized as Other/Neutral Content, as they serve as narrative framing and divine pronouncements that don't neatly fit into the other categories. The phrase 'worthy is the lamb' is absent, so Worship & Praise is low, but the idea of God dwelling with humanity suggests a degree of reverence. Lament is present in the removal of tears and pain, but it is minimal. There is no explicit Cosmic Warfare.

The phrase "Γράψον, ὅτι οὗτοι οἱ λόγοι πιστοὶ καὶ ἀληθινοί εἰσιν" (Write, for these words are trustworthy and true) is a Prophetic Exhortation. The description of the fate of the cowardly, unbelieving, and immoral in the lake of fire (Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action) contrasts sharply with the promise to the one who thirsts and overcomes (Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope). The vision of the city descending from heaven evokes 'Theophanic Awe & Terror' (15%). The rest of the passage is narrative and descriptive, falling under 'Other/Neutral Content' (45%), including the angel's introduction and the description of the mountain.

The passage primarily describes the New Jerusalem, emphasizing its beauty and glory. 'ἔχουσαν τὴν δόξαν τοῦ θεοῦ' and descriptions of precious stones contribute to the 'Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope' (35%) and 'Theophanic Awe & Terror' (8%) categories. The statement 'καὶ οἱ δοῦλοι αὐτοῦ λατρεύσουσιν αὐτῷ' and 'κύριος ὁ θεὸς φωτίσει ἐπʼ αὐτούς, καὶ βασιλεύσουσιν εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων' clearly indicates 'Worship & Praise' (15%). 'καὶ οὐ μὴ εἰσέλθῃ εἰς αὐτὴν πᾶν κοινὸν καὶ ποιῶν βδέλυγμα καὶ ψεῦδος' is a 'Prophetic Exhortation & Warning' (5%). The detailed descriptions of the city's dimensions, materials, and layout, such as 'καὶ ἡ πόλις τετράγωνος κεῖται' and the list of foundation stones, fall under 'Other/Neutral Content' (35%) as they are primarily descriptive and do not strongly align with the other categories. 'καὶ πᾶν κατάθεμα οὐκ ἔσται ἔτι' suggests a removal of judgment, thus 'Judicial Wrath & Punitive Action' is at 2%.

The passage primarily describes the New Jerusalem, emphasizing its beauty and glory. 'ἔχουσαν τὴν δόξαν τοῦ θεοῦ' and 'ἡ γὰρ δόξα τοῦ θεοῦ ἐφώτισεν αὐτήν' highlight God's glory (Worship & Praise, Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope). The description of the city's materials and structure ('λίθῳ τιμιωτάτῳ', 'τεῖχος μέγα καὶ ὑψηλόν', 'χρυσίον καθαρὸν') falls under Other/Neutral Content as descriptive narrative. 'καὶ οὐ μὴ εἰσέλθῃ εἰς αὐτὴν πᾶν κοινὸν καὶ ποιῶν βδέλυγμα καὶ ψεῦδος' implies a warning (Prophetic Exhortation & Warning). The river of life and tree of life contribute to the Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope theme. 'καὶ πᾶν κατάθεμα οὐκ ἔσται ἔτι' further reinforces this. The absence of a temple ('ναὸν οὐκ εἶδον ἐν αὐτῇ') and the statement that God and the Lamb are the temple contribute to Theophanic Awe & Terror, as does the description of the river flowing from the throne. The lack of night ('νὺξ οὐκ ἔσται ἔτι') also contributes to the Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope theme.

The passage contains elements of prophetic assurance and exhortation ('Οὗτοι οἱ λόγοι πιστοὶ καὶ ἀληθινοί,' 'ἰδοὺ ἔρχομαι ταχύ,' 'μακάριος ὁ τηρῶν'), which accounts for 35%. The angel's command to worship God ('τῷ θεῷ προσκύνησον') contributes to the 'Worship & Praise' category (15%). The phrase 'ἃ δεῖ γενέσθαι ἐν τάχει' hints at future events and the coming of the Lord, suggesting 'Victory, Consolation & New-Creation Hope' (10%). John's initial reaction of falling down to worship the angel and the angel's correction evokes 'Theophanic Awe & Terror' (10%). The remaining content, including narrative elements and descriptions, is categorized as 'Other/Neutral Content' (30%).

The passage contains elements of prophetic exhortation and warning ('μακάριος ὁ τηρῶν τοὺς λόγους τῆς προφητείας τοῦ βιβλίου τούτου', 'Ὅρα μή'), hope ('ἰδοὺ ἔρχομαι ταχύ'), worship ('τῷ θεῷ προσκύνησον'), theophanic awe ('ἔπεσα προσκυνῆσαι ἔμπροσθεν τῶν ποδῶν τοῦ ἀγγέλου'), and neutral content ('Καὶ εἶπέν μοι', 'Κἀγὼ Ἰωάννης ὁ ἀκούων καὶ βλέπων ταῦτα'). The 'faithful and true' declaration and the angel's explanation are categorized as 'Other/Neutral Content' because they serve as narrative framing and clarification, not fitting neatly into the other categories. The phrase 'ὁ θεὸς τῶν πνευμάτων τῶν προφητῶν' contributes to the worship aspect.

The passage contains prophetic exhortation and warning ('Μὴ σφραγίσῃς', 'ὁ ἀδικῶν ἀδικησάτω ἔτι', 'ἐάν τις ἐπιθῇ', 'ἐάν τις ἀφέλῃ'), judicial wrath ('ἐπιθήσει ὁ θεὸς ἐπʼ αὐτὸν τὰς πληγὰς', 'ἀφελεῖ ὁ θεὸς τὸ μέρος αὐτοῦ'), victory and new creation hope ('ἡ ἐξουσία αὐτῶν ἐπὶ τὸ ξύλον τῆς ζωῆς', 'εἰσέλθωσιν εἰς τὴν πόλιν', 'ὕδωρ ζωῆς δωρεάν'), worship ('ἔρχου, κύριε Ἰησοῦ', 'Ἡ χάρις τοῦ κυρίου Ἰησοῦ μετὰ πάντων'), cosmic warfare ('ἔξω οἱ κύνες καὶ οἱ φάρμακοι καὶ οἱ πόρνοι καὶ οἱ φονεῖς καὶ οἱ εἰδωλολάτραι καὶ πᾶς φιλῶν καὶ ποιῶν ψεῦδος'), theophanic awe ('ἐγὼ τὸ Ἄλφα καὶ τὸ Ὦ, ὁ πρῶτος καὶ ὁ ἔσχατος, ἡ ἀρχὴ καὶ τὸ τέλος', 'ἐγώ εἰμι ἡ ῥίζα καὶ τὸ γένος Δαυίδ, ὁ ἀστὴρ ὁ λαμπρός, ὁ πρωϊνός'), and other/neutral content includes narrative elements and descriptions that don't fit neatly into the other categories ('Καὶ λέγει μοι', 'Μαρτυρῶ ἐγὼ παντὶ τῷ ἀκούοντι').

The passage contains a mix of prophetic exhortation and warning ('Μὴ σφραγίσῃς', 'ὁ ἀδικῶν ἀδικησάτω ἔτι', 'ἐάν τις ἐπιθῇ', 'ἐάν τις ἀφέλῃ'), promises of reward and judgment ('ὁ μισθός μου μετʼ ἐμοῦ', 'ἀποδοῦναι ἑκάστῳ ὡς τὸ ἔργον ἐστὶν αὐτοῦ'), descriptions of the blessed ('Μακάριοι οἱ πλύνοντες τὰς στολὰς αὐτῶν'), and lists of those excluded ('ἔξω οἱ κύνες').
